text: Don’t be a space goop; drink from a cup that has wings.  Students, don’t try this at home.  https://t.co/SCk706m0Zj https://t.co/LKWMMlnwCF
Form makes function; two angled walls make a cusp at the lip. Wings keeps you of dribbling.  https://t.co/SCk706m0Zj https://t.co/l2m2zkX7CM
Good engineering; when mathematics serves both function and aesthetics; vs2 Space Cup: https://t.co/SCk706m0Zj https://t.co/1sj2dsHcb4
The space cup is more than sipping tea with style in space;  geek out with the math: https://t.co/SCk706m0Zj https://t.co/9Ub4QgTEfR
Space toast with space cups; crew tea toast to celebrate a good day in space. details: https://t.co/SCk706m0Zj https://t.co/nvHfto6GG9

2/26/2016
The space cup in space:  The tea flows to the lip along the channel. https://t.co/SCk706m0Zj https://t.co/q3OgXDo4nR
capillary-driven channel flow; like a straw with only two sides.  https://t.co/SCk706m0Zj https://t.co/vkNrFVucqC
The geometry of vs1 space cup looks a lot like a symmetrical airplane wing.  see why: https://t.co/SCk706m0Zj https://t.co/vnCZQDDLEG
While on orbit, I found some transparent laserjet printer sheets that work with our onboard inkjet printer, more at: https://t.co/SCk706m0Zj
How does space cup work?  It has to be made from a wetting material: https://t.co/YX02iIQFTf https://t.co/IBo4JZaaIm
Necessity is the mother of invention; this applies to life in space as well as on Earth; https://t.co/SCk706m0Zj https://t.co/5YIhYdE7BN
Before the space cup, you could drink tea with chopsticks: https://t.co/SCk706m0Zj or https://t.co/ddAL487GFT https://t.co/YjWWTo6vbQ
The simple pleasantries of drinking from an cup in space have not been possible until now; https://t.co/2ari4ExN0f
A normal drinking glass or mug will not work in space.  See why https://t.co/BnuH4XK4xc

I will be sitting in my rocket watching everyone on Earth move off into the frontier.  Thus I  say to all, “Godspeed”. http://t.co/oO90gUWj
Space Station over baikonur with Russian, Netherlands, US, and Kazakhstan flags in -18 degree breeze. http://t.co/zNx3aMe8
Four days ago our rocket was in pieces, now it stands ready for tomorrows launch.  Read the story: http://t.co/b3cW2BwR http://t.co/W5mkgDRo
Four days from launch and our rocket is still in pieces.  They will come together in one day. http://t.co/Cos14HyI http://t.co/gVywHc8W
Our Soyuz spacecraft on its assembly stand.  This was our last chance for a look-see until launch. http://t.co/qN0DD5qD
Zero gravity chickens; spin an egg, can you tell the difference; hard boiled or fresh?  Find out at:  http://t.co/sw8xvGxd
Blowup astronauts; drying our suit after wearing them.  See why at: http://t.co/quy7vRBi http://t.co/SoptffNZ

Welcome to Baikonur.  We are making our final stages of preparation. http://t.co/vJLHqsHn
Landing in Baikonur; this place makes Kansas seem mountainous. http://t.co/dgxLahSb

New Brunswick region in Canada. Cities at Night mosaic assembled from images taken during Exp 6.  I will take more. http://t.co/b3jNfAwH
Gourmet food in a can, Russian style. Extreme but not for pleasure.  Image from Dan Tani, Exp 16. http://t.co/SgG11Z8I
A sample of French space food from our ESA colleagues.  It is labeled "Food for Extreme Pleasure".  Gourmet in a can. http://t.co/LW5yG7rH
I have had some requests for my Twitter background collage.  I assembled this from pictures taken on Exp 6 or STS 126. http://t.co/wztxODgb

See a picture of Exp 28 Soyuz making its first orbital pass over Baikonur.  It came by 88 minutes after launch. http://t.co/VUHlsJJI
Antares is a star in Scorpio.  Antares is also Exp 30 Soyuz callsign.  Check out this photo taken in Baikonur http://t.co/VUHlsJJI
I am preparing for my next mission by posting some of my Exp 6 work astro_pettit's photostream http://t.co/jfGYPJse
